abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan reviews
            the adverse effects on the livelihoods of affected
            populations, as a result of the Metro Manila Urban Transport
            Integration Project, and examines the right of way (ROW)
            issue facing the Don Mariano Marcos Avenue extension, as
            well as issues related to the Marikina Bridge, and its
            access road component. The ROW is a Government's
            responsibility in regards to its alignment, and
            compensation; local governments were included in discussions
            on possible cost-sharing, and on the valuation of the ROW
            costs. As of those discussions, the project area was cleared
            for project implementation, though socioeconomic impacts did
            occur as a result of demolitions, removal of trees, and,
            adversity to farmland, and private residential land in the
            Industrial Valley. However, land acquisition is no longer an
            issue: properties along the ROW of the access road, and
            Marikina Bridge are government owned, donated in January
            1995, while private land should not be affected by the
            project, based on an agreed new scheme. Affected
            populations, mainly squatter families, were relocated to
            different sites (government, or privately owned), of easy
            access to job opportunities. Construction materials for
            temporary shelters, transportation, and food assistance were
            provided, and, displaced persons were encouraged to organize
            as a community, with the provision of government assistance,
            and training. Currently, monitoring concerns employment
            problems, security measures at resettlement sites, and a
            continuing technical assistance in the provision of infrastructure.
